title: Pervasiveness and efficacy in regulatory governance : neo-liberalism as ideology and practice in European telecommunications reorganisation

references.title: Communication from the Commission to the Council, the European Parliament,
Communication from the Commission to the European Parliament, the Council,
Constitutionalising Capital: EMU and Disciplinary Neoliberalism’, in Andreas Bieler and A. Morton (eds) ‘Social Forces in the Making of the New Europe: the Restructuring of
Extending European Cooperation: The European Union and the ‘New’ International Trade Agenda, Manchester:
Proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council Amending Directive 2002/22/EC on Universal Service and Users’ Rights Relating to Electronic Communications Networks,
Proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council Establishing the European Electronic Communications Market Authority’,
Proposal for Directive Amending Directives 2002/21/ EC on a Common Regulatory Framework for Electronic Communications Networks and Services,
Regulation (EC) No 2887/2000 of the European Parliament and of the
Regulation after delegation: independent regulatory agencies in Europe’,
Regulatory change and telecommunications governance: a neo-Gramscian analysis’, Convergence:
The Changing Totems of European Telecommunications Governance: Liberalisation,

abstract:
Paper presented to the European Consortium for Political Research Standing Group
on Regulatory Governance Second Biennial Conference, ‘(Re)Regulation in the Wake
of Neoliberalism. Consequences of Three Decades of Privatization and Market
Liberalization’, Utrecht, Netherlands, June 5-7, 2008. Full-text is available at http://regulation.upf.edu/utrecht-08-papers/ssimpson.pdf
rawRecordXml:
<record><header><identifier>
oai:www.e-space.mmu.ac.uk:2173/73954</identifier><datestamp>2009-07-15T14:18:41Z</datestamp><setSpec>hdl_2173_682</setSpec><setSpec>hdl_2173_670</setSpec></header><metadata><oai_dc:dc xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/" xmlns:oai_dc="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc/ http://www.openarchives.org/OAI/2.0/oai_dc.xsd" ><dc:title>Pervasiveness and efficacy in regulatory governance : neo-liberalism as ideology and practice in European telecommunications reorganisation</dc:title><dc:creator>Simpson, Seamus</dc:creator><dc:description>Telecommunications provides one of the most well-developed examples of the growth of neo-liberalism. The sector is interesting since the contrast between its pre neoliberal
and post neo-liberal characteristics is particularly stark. This paper explores the
impacts of neo-liberalism in European telecommunications, placing particular focus
on the EU institutional context. It considers the conseqences of neo-liberalism as ideology, on the one hand, and practice, on the other. It finds that, ideologically, neoliberalism has become deeply pervasive in European telecommunications and for its
advocates can be regarded as a highly successful project spanning almost 30 years. In terms of practice, the paper argues that the pursuit of neo-liberalism has been less
successful. In particular, competition has proven complex and difficult to create and
there are concerns over the ability of the neo-liberal model to provide sufficient
investment to deliver new Next Generation Networks. However, these deficiencies
tend to be under-played due to the ideological and rhetorical success of the neo-liberal project in telecommunications.</dc:description><dc:description>Paper presented to the European Consortium for Political Research Standing Group
on Regulatory Governance Second Biennial Conference, ‘(Re)Regulation in the Wake
of Neoliberalism. Consequences of Three Decades of Privatization and Market
Liberalization’, Utrecht, Netherlands, June 5-7, 2008. Full-text is available at http://regulation.upf.edu/utrecht-08-papers/ssimpson.pdf</dc:description><dc:publisher>European Consortium for Political Research</dc:publisher><dc:date>2009-07-15T15:18:41Z</dc:date><dc:type>Presentation</dc:type><dc:type>Meetings and Proceedings</dc:type><dc:identifier>http://hdl.handle.net/2173/73954</dc:identifier><dc:language>en</dc:language><dc:relation>http://regulation.upf.edu/index.php?id=conferences_projects</dc:relation><dc:relation>http://regulation.upf.edu/utrecht-08-papers/ssimpson.pdf</dc:relation></oai_dc:dc></metadata></record>
